problem_statement: Derive the vector and Cartesian equations of a plane that is at a perpendicular distance p from the origin and is perpendicular to a given unit normal vector d̂. Also state the special case when the plane passes through the origin and write the standard form when the given normal need not be a unit vector.

step_details.explanation: Name the key points and vectors from the diagram.
expressions: $O \text{ is the origin, } A \text{ is the foot of the perpendicular from } O \text{ to the plane.}$
$\hat{d} \text{ is a unit normal to the plane (i.e., } \lVert \hat{d} \rVert = 1\text{).}$

step_details.explanation: Pick an arbitrary point P on the plane and write vectors using position vectors.
expressions: $\vec{r} = \overrightarrow{OP} \quad \color{blue}{\text{(position vector of a general point }P\text{ on the plane)}}$

step_details.explanation: Use the right-angle condition between the perpendicular and the plane.
expressions: $\overrightarrow{AP} \perp \overrightarrow{OA} \;\Rightarrow\; (\vec{r} - p\,\hat{d}) \cdot \hat{d} = 0 \quad \color{blue}{\text{(dot product zero for perpendicular vectors)}}$

step_details.explanation: Expand the dot product and use that d̂ is a unit vector.
Convert to Cartesian form using direction cosines.
expressions: $\hat{d} = l\,\hat{i} + m\,\hat{j} + n\,\hat{k} \quad \color{blue}{\text{(}l,m,n\text{ are direction cosines)}}$

step_details.explanation: State the special case when the plane passes through the origin.
Write the standard form when the given normal d is not a unit vector.
